Asia Regional Integration Center, Phase II

members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

Team member  J. Duque, Economics Officer, OREI

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Economies in the Asia and Pacific region are becoming more deeply and strongly linked. 
To enhance the economic potential of the region, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) established 
the Office of Regional Economic Integration (OREI) in 2005 and adopted a regional cooperation 
and integration (RCI) strategy1 in July 2006 to facilitate and coordinate ADB’s efforts and to raise 
ADB’s profile at key RCI events. OREI launched the Asia Regional Integration Center (ARIC) 
website in October 2006 to provide information on the progress of RCI initiatives in the region 
under the four pillars of the RCI strategy: (i) cross-border infrastructure and associated software, (ii) 
trade and investment, (iii) money and finance, and (iv) regional public goods. Since its launch, the 
ARIC website has become an authoritative source of RCI information. 
 
2.  As RCI continues to evolve, so does the work to promote and support it. Web statistics and 
user surveys indicate that ARIC already provides a platform for consolidating and disseminating 
information on RCI. These successes need to be built upon. This technical assistance (TA) paper 
describes the purpose and output, methodology and key activities, cost estimates and financing 
plan, and implementation arrangements of the second phase of ARIC. The design and monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Integration in the Asia and Pacific region has been gaining momentum. Intraregional trade 
in East Asia (as a percentage of the region’s total trade) alone rose from 43% in 1990 to 55% in 
2006. 3  The  pace  of  integration  has  been  largely  market-driven 4  and  has  recently  been 
characterized by national trade and investment liberalization and a proliferation of free trade 
agreements.  Asian  countries  have  also  intensified  cooperation  in  infrastructure  and  capacity 
building, money and finance, and regional public goods. ADB has been at the forefront of efforts to 
promote  regional  cooperation  and  has  played  a  major  role  in  supporting  regional  economic 
initiatives.  
 
4.  As Asia moves toward greater integration, ADB’s support for RCI is expected to increase in 
importance. In addition to OREI, which facilitates and coordinates ADB’s RCI support, the regional 
departments were realigned in 2006 to improve the coherence of ADB’s regional operations, and 
to strengthen the synergy between country and regional operations. The five regional departments 
were given responsibility for pillar 1 of the RCI strategy in close collaboration with ADB’s Private 
Sector Operations Department (PSOD) and Office of Cofinancing Operations (OCO). OREI was 
given primary responsibility for pillars 2 and 3 while responsibility for pillar 4 given to ADB’s 
Regional and Sustainable Department (RSDD), supported by ADB’s Office of General Counsel 
(OGC).

5.  The ARIC website traces its roots from a website called the Asia Recovery Information 
Center,5 set up in 1999 to provide accurate, timely, and comprehensive information on economies 
affected by the 1997–1998 financial crisis. As the recovery took off, the scope of the website 
expanded. The number of visitors to the ARIC website has steadily increased and in 2007 the 
average number of daily visitors reached about 850, an increase of about 9% from the fourth 
quarter of 2006 (780 average daily visitors). During major events, the number of ARIC visitors 
peaked at about 1,400 per day. 
 
6.  Since its launch, the ARIC website has served as a clearinghouse for RCI information from 
ADB and other sources on the 48 regional member countries of ADB. Information on 45 regional 
initiatives and/or programs is organized according to the four key pillars of the RCI strategy. 
Headline news, opinion and editorials, research, and related links are updated daily. The ARIC 
website has also served as the main dissemination platform for papers on RCI and reports on 
macroeconomic developments in the region.   
 
7.  ARIC also houses databases. The RCI indicators database is a statistical tool that features 
a  set  of  integration  indicators  to  monitor  progress  in  RCI.  The  free  trade  agreement  (FTA) 
database tracks almost 200 FTAs in Asia and the Pacific. An FTA comparative toolkit allows users 
to compare sections of different FTA agreement texts easily.   
 
8.  The existing ARIC website highlights original research by OREI, including the working 
paper series on regional economic integration, which provides in-depth analysis of major issues 
relating to RCI. To date, 14 working papers have been produced and a lot of research is in the 
pipeline. Some working papers have been cited by international media. The website also covers 
the  seminar  series  on  regional  economic  integration  organized  by  OREI,  which  has  brought 
together 10 speakers to discuss issues covering the four RCI pillars.      
 
9.  The Asian macroeconomic development section continues the approach of the original 
Asia  Recovery  Information  Center.  It  has  a  dedicated  readership  from  users  monitoring 
macroeconomic developments in the region. A key component is the Asia Economic Monitor (AEM) 
which provides a semiannual review and outlook on growth of the section and development in 
emerging  Asia.  15  issues  of  the  AEM  have  been  published  and  widely  disseminated  in 
international media. This section also includes an economic and financial indicators database, 
providing users with statistical data on the real, external, monetary, and financial sectors of 15 
economies from East Asia and 4 economies from South Asia6.  
 
10.  Other  institutions  have  used  the  ARIC  website  as  a  benchmark  in  developing  their 
websites. ARIC has been consulted by the Secretariat for the Common Market for Eastern and 
Southern Africa, which plans to establish a regional integration surveillance mechanism. The ARIC 
website was also included in the United Nations University, Center for Comparative Regional 
Integration Studies in its best-practice analysis of online resources dealing with integration studies. 
As an example of its growing influence, ARIC assisted the Association of Southeast Asian Nations 
Secretariat (ASEC) to create a website for its statistical unit and is helping ASEC to develop an

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The objective of the TA is to strengthen the dissemination of information and knowledge on 
RCI in the Asia and Pacific region. This will involve maintaining the ARIC website, regularly 
updating its content, increasing its country coverage in some sections of the site and undertaking 
more content and web interface enhancements. As the number of knowledge resources on RCI 
grows, more working and occasional papers will be published, including economic monitoring 
reports, and more seminars and workshops on regional economic integration will be held.  
 
12.  The TA will increase awareness of Asian regional cooperation and integration initiatives 
among various stakeholders, such as government officials both at the policy-making and technical 
levels, academic researchers, officials and staff of international institutions, private sector users, 
and journalists, as well as ADB Management and staff. The use of reliable and comprehensive 
information by key stakeholders and ADB staff will result in better regional cooperation policies 
and more appropriate and well-designed regional projects. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  The  TA  will  undertake  several  interrelated  tasks,  all  directed  at  strengthening  the 
dissemination of information and knowledge on RCI in the Asia and Pacific region and raising 
awareness. These include (i) maintaining and enhancing the ARIC website, (ii) supporting the 
ADB  seminar  series  on  regional  economic  integration,  (iii)  supporting  the  ADB  working  and 
occasional paper series on regional economic integration, and (iv) supporting the preparation of 
AEM and other OREI research activities. The TA will cover all ADB DMCs. Assistance will not be 
undertaken in any DMCs until ADB receives a notice of no objection from the government. 
 
14.  Enhancements will be made to the web interface and content of the ARIC website. More 
content summaries will be made available at the home page to provide users with a quick guide to 
the  website.  Software  and  hardware  will  be  purchased  to  enable  more  interactive  website 
presentations.  
 
15.  The list of initiatives featured under the four RCI pillars will be reviewed and expanded. The 
scope of the regional public goods pillar will be expanded to include emerging issues such as 
climate change and this will require more collaboration among RSDD, OGC, and OREI.  Links with 
knowledge products of subregional initiatives (e.g., the Brunei Darussalam-Indonesia-Malaysia-
Philippines East ASEAN Growth Area trade and investment database) will be strengthened.  
 
16.  The RCI indicators database will be expanded to include more economies, subregional 
groupings (especially those supported by ADB), sectoral data, and other statistical measures of 
regional integration for the four RCI pillars. When choosing RCI indicators, attention will be paid to 
ensuring that these are consistent with those in the statistics section of ADB’s main website.

17.  Links of the ARIC website to the main ADB main website will be strengthened by promoting 
sharing and linking of resources. OREI will also take an active role in developing and improving 
the regional cooperation web page in the ADB main website. More collaborative undertakings will 
be explored with other institutions. Links to international best practices on RCI outside the region 
will also be developed.    
 
18.  The TA will explore the possibility of incorporating new features such as newsletter-type 
online publications and discussion forums. Customized knowledge products will be developed to 
target specific users of the ARIC website. A daily update of the website will ensure that the latest 
ADB-wide and external information on RCI is uploaded. OREI will use advice and information from 
the network of contact points for the website in various ADB departments to improve website 
content. Efforts will be made to expand this network within and outside ADB. 
 
19.  Five to seven seminars will be held during the TA implementation period. Four to six 
working  papers  and  three  or  four  occasional  papers  will  be  produced  and  disseminated  in 
collaboration  with  the  ADB  Department  of  External  Relations  (DER).  ADB  staff  and  key 
stakeholders will be invited to contribute to the seminars and paper series. 
 
20.  Three  issues  of  the  AEM  will  be  produced  for  online  publication  during  the  TA 
implementation  period.  These  will  cover  Association  of  Southeast  Asian  Nations  (ASEAN) 
countries;  the  People’s  Republic  of  China;  Hong  Kong,  China;  Republic  of  Korea;  and 
Taipei,China as previously, and possibly also South and Central Asian countries. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
21.  The total cost of the TA, estimated at $900,000, will be financed on a grant basis from 
ADB’s TA funding program. The cost will cover remuneration, honoraria, travel, and per diem for 
international and national consultants and resource persons, database subscriptions, computer 
hardware and software, publications, communications and supplies, seminar and meeting costs, 
and other costs. The detailed cost estimates and the financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
22.  ADB will be the Executing Agency for the TA. OREI will implement the TA, in close 
collaboration with other ADB departments and offices. The community of practice on regional 
cooperation and integration will provide advice and guidance as required. 
 
23.  The TA will require about 32 person-months of international and 147 person-months of 
national consulting services. All the consultants will be hired as individual consultants according to 
ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time).  Terms of 
reference for the consultants are outlined in Appendix 3.  
 
24.  One international consultant—an economist with expertise in trade, macroeconomic, and 
development issues in Asia—will be made the team leader. Under the supervision of ADB staff, 
this consultant will oversee other consultants who will develop and maintain the ARIC website as 
well as other ARIC activities. Other international consultants—economists familiar with trade, 
macroeconomic, and development issues in Asia, particularly the ADB DMCs, and with strong 
analytical  and  communication  skills—will  help  prepare  special  studies  on  topical  issues  with 
significant policy implications for regional cooperation and integration.  An economics and copy 
editor will also draft contents of the ARIC website, and edit AEM reports and OREI working papers.

5
25.  National  consultants  will  maintain  the  ARIC  website.  Three  web  specialists  (web 
programmer, administrator and graphics and publication designer) will be hired. Seven national 
consultants (one deputy team leader, five economic analysts, and a desk-top publisher) will assist 
the team leader in developing and operating the website and performing other research activities.  
 
26.  About five resource persons will also be hired to provide 0.6 person-months of resource 
persons’ services for the ADB seminar series on regional economic integration. The resource 
persons will be international experts on the four pillars, specializing in regional cooperation and 
integration issues, or policy makers who are considered prime movers of Asian integration. Terms 
of reference for the resource persons are outlined in Appendix 3. 
 
27.  Computer  hardware  and  software  will  be  procured  by  ADB  according  to  ADB's 
Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time) and in coordination with ADB’s 
Office of Information Systems and Technology and Office of Administrative Services.  
 
28.  The TA is expected to be implemented over 18 months, from May 2008 to October 2009. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
29.  The  President,  acting  under  the  authority  delegated  by  the  Board,  has  approved  the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $900,000 on a grant basis for the 
Asia Regional Integration Center, Phase II, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Team Leader (international, 18 person-months) 
1.  The  consultant  will  be  an  economist  with  expertise  in  trade,  macroeconomic,  and 
development issues in the Asia and Pacific region, at least 10 years of relevant work experience, 
including project management and experience handling multidisciplinary teams; and strong 
analytical, liaison, and communication skills. Under the supervision of the Office of Regional 
Economic Integration (OREI) staff, the consultant will: 
 
(i)  manage the daily operations and development of the Asian Regional Integration 
Center (ARIC) website; 
(ii)  evaluate the structure and operational procedures of the ARIC website, and 
advise on how to improve and expand it; 
(iii)  oversee the improvement, expansion, and daily operations of the ARIC website; 
(iv)  assist  in  the  preparation  of  the  Asia  Economic  Monitor  (AEM)  by  preparing 
country reports for Asian economies to cover (a) recent economic performance 
and growth prospects; (b) economic and financial vulnerabilities and risks; and 
(c) policy reforms and emerging structural issues and challenges; 
(v)  coordinate with  relevant  offices,  including  government  agencies,  international 
organizations, and aid agencies and liaise with various Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) departments and offices; and 
(vi)  prepare regular reports on ARIC operations, expenditures and implementation. 
 
B.  Deputy Team Leader (national, 18 person-months) 
2.  The consultant will be competent to carry out supervisory tasks and will have extensive 
knowledge of economic and policy issues in the region, adequate background on database 
development and management, strong proficiency in data processing and analysis, familiarity 
with computer applications used in economic analysis, and good communication skills. Under 
the supervision of OREI staff and the ARIC team leader, the national consultant will perform the 
following tasks. 
1.  Supervisory Work  
 
(i)  Perform the tasks of the team leader, in his or her absence; 
(ii)  assist in the management of the daily operations of the ARIC website, including 
approving daily website upload of content work done by ARIC team members; 
(iii)  help to implement the ARIC work plan by ensuring that performance plans of 
ARIC team members are carried out;    
(iv)  assist in the management of capacity building projects undertaken by ARIC with 
its stakeholders (e.g., Association of Southeast Asian Nations Secretariat);  
(v)  help to supervise technical work done by ARIC team members; 
(vi)  support the team leader to prepare management reports related to ARIC; and  
(vii)  liaise with ADB departments and other stakeholders on ARIC-related matters.

Appendix 3  11 
2.  Research Work  
 
(i)  Provide research support for the preparation of the AEM by preparing country 
notes and providing data support; 
(ii)  carry out data and research requests from OREI management; 
(iii)  oversee enhancements (both front-end and back-end interfaces) to the indicator-
related databases for the website, including the macroeconomic and financial 
indicators  database  and  the  regional  cooperation  and  integration  indicators 
database; and  
(iv)  oversee updating of the money and finance section of the ARIC website. 
 
C.  Economists (international, total 4 person-months) 
3.  International  consultants  will  be  hired  to  undertake  special  studies  on  regional 
cooperation  and  integration.  The  consultants  will  be  economists  familiar  with  trade, 
macroeconomic,  and  development  issues in  the  Asia  and  Pacific  region,  and  have  strong 
analytical and communication skills. Under the supervision of OREI staff, the consultants will: 
 
(i)  prepare special studies on regional cooperation and integration; and  
(ii)  revise and finalize the study on the basis of comments received from OREI and 
other departments or offices. 
 
D.  Economics and Copy Editors (international, total 10 person-months) 
4.  The consultant(s) will edit the ARIC website content and TA-supported publications, 
including the AEM. The consultant(s) should be familiar with economic and development issues 
in the Asia and Pacific region, and have strong communication skills. Under the supervision of 
OREI staff and the team leader, the consultant(s) will ensure that edited materials adhere to 
ADB style and usage and conform to high publication standards. The consultant(s) will: 
 
(i)  draft  contents  of  the  ARIC  website,  AEM  reports,  OREI  working  papers, 
management statements, press releases, and other technical documents; 
(ii)  draft articles and notes on regional cooperation and integration for international 
publications; 
(iii)  examine economic arguments in documents to assess whether they are logical 
and are based on accepted economic theory and principles; 
(iv)  rewrite, add, or delete information, and revise the order of statements or sections 
of various documents, if necessary, to tighten the economic arguments, fill in 
gaps in the discussions, and ensure a smoother flow of ideas; 
(v)  examine  the  tables,  figures,  and  charts  in  the  documents  to  ensure  data 
consistency within the report and suggest deletions and additions to ensure that 
the tables, figures, and charts are useful; and  
(vi)  ensure that edited materials adhere to ADB style and usage and conform to high 
publication standards. 
 
E.  Web Administrators and Programmers (national, total 27 person-months) 
5.  Two consultants will help the team leader expand, improve, and operate the ARIC 
website. Under the supervision of OREI staff and the ARIC team leader, the consultants will: 
 
(i)  improve and expand the ARIC website;

Appendix 3  13 
 
H.  Desktop Publisher (national, 3 person-months) 
8.  The consultant will lay out at least three issues of the AEM and convert the files into the 
required format for print and/or online publication. In consultation with and under the guidance of 
OREI staff, the consultant will:  
 
(i)  lay out the text, tables, and charts of the AEM in Adobe Indesign CS2 and Adobe 
Illustrator CS2;  
(ii)  incorporate revisions to the text, tables, and charts;  
(iii)  convert the Adobe files into PDF files for online and print publication. 
 
I.  Resource Persons (international, total 0.6 person-months) 
9.  Approximately five consultants will be engaged as resource persons to participate as 
discussants  in  workshops  and  seminars.  These  resource  persons  will  be  internationally 
distinguished experts on the four pillars of the RCI strategy (main text, para. 1) or policy makers 
who are considered prime movers of Asian integration.
